s0001: Xiang Ji was from Xiapi, styled Yu.
s0002: When he first rose up, he was twenty-four years old.
s0003: His uncle Xiang Liang; Liang's father was the Chu general Xiang Yan, who was executed by the Qin general Wang Jian.
s0004: The Xiang clan generation after generation served as Chu generals, enfeoffed at Xiang, therefore surnamed Xiang.
s0005: When Xiang Ji was young, he studied writing but did not succeed, then went to study swordsmanship, and again did not succeed.
s0006: Xiang Liang was angry with him.
s0007: Ji said: 'Writing is enough only to record names and surnames.
s0008: Swordsmanship fights one man, not worth studying; study to fight ten thousand men.'
s0009: Therefore Xiang Liang taught Ji military strategy; Ji was greatly pleased, grasped the general meaning, but again would not complete the study.
s0010: Xiang Liang once had a warrant from Queyang, so asked the Qi prison clerk Cao Jiu to write a letter to the Queyang prison clerk Sima Xin, and through precedents it was resolved.
s0011: Xiang Liang killed someone, and with Ji fled enmity to Wu.
s0012: Wu generals were often subordinate to Xiang Liang.
s0013: When Chen Sheng first rose, the Wu guards wanted to respond, but Xiang Liang said: 'Chen Sheng is a commoner, cannot amount to much.'
s0014: When the Wu guards heard of the defeat of Chen Sheng and Wu Guang, they planned to kill Xiang Liang.
s0015: Xiang Liang escaped, Ji said: 'I can take them.'
s0016: Xiang Liang said: 'The world is in chaos, ghosts and spirits are moving, it is the time for great action.'
s0017: He forged a letter from Chen Sheng to the Wu guards, ordering Xiang Liang to lead the Wu troops, Xiang Liang as general, Ji as deputy general.
s0018: He summoned all the worthy and strong of Wu, and the young men who followed him numbered eight thousand.
s0019: He led them east, attacking the Qin forces.
s0020: When Xiang Liang reached Xiapi, he heard that Chen Sheng had been defeated and killed.
s0021: He then summoned the nobles of the six states, established Xiang Liang as the leader of the nobles.
s0025: Attacked Dingtao, defeated Qin forces there.
s0026: Xiang Liang greatly expanded, his troops numbered sixty to seventy thousand.
s0027: He made Yuan Gong the prime minister, Fan Zeng the strategist.
s0028: Fan Zeng advised Xiang Liang to establish a descendant of the Chu royal family as king to win the people's hearts.
s0029: He found Xiong Xin, grandson of King Huai of Chu, established him as King Huai of Chu, with Pengcheng as capital.
s0030: King Huai made Xiang Liang 'Supreme General', gave him a seal, ordered him to attack the west.
s0031: Xiang Liang attacked Yongqiu, took it.
s0035: Xiang Liang grew arrogant, did not listen to advice.
s0036: The Qin general Zhang Han attacked Xiang Liang, defeated him at Dingtao, Xiang Liang was killed.
s0037: Xiang Liang's death caused the Chu army to lose heart, the nobles scattered.
s0038: King Huai moved the capital to Yinque.
s0039: Xiang Liang's nephew Xiang Ji and Fan Zeng collected the remaining troops, retreated east to Pengcheng.
s0040: They sent messengers to seek Xiang Liang's body, buried it in Yinling.
